abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Primary Education
            Project for Nepal was satisfactory. The project achieved
            many of its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development was partially satisfactory, and sustainability
            is likely. However, both the Bank and Borrower acted less
            than satisfactorily overall. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, the project did not impose
            unrealistic targets on the sector. Second, macroeconomic
            performance and general administrative and staffing policies
            have an impact on project performance. Third, well prepared,
            timely, and well supervised pilot projects can succeed in
            focusing public attention on the sector, make positive
            impacts, and test the ground for national full-scale
            expansion. Lastly, strengthening the administrative and
            technical capacity of the sector is difficult to achieve
            without integration of project and line ministry functions.
